newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine stocks close lower, await U.S. data.
newsitem.headline: Argentine stocks close lower, await U.S. data.

text.p: Argentine stocks continued their downward drift Thursday in slow trading and braced for Friday's U.S. inflation data, dealers said.

"Today we followed through on the week's negative tone, with a lot of apathy because the outlook isn't clear in the United States or in Brazil," said Dario Lizzano, head of research at Santander Investments, referring to U.S. interest rate concerns and Brazil's fiscal woes.
The blue-chip MerVal index .MERV, however, pulled off a session floor of 700.49 in late trading and closed at 705.91, with a 1.0 percent loss.
Floor volume remained extremely weak at 16.9 million pesos against 14.7 million Wednesday, while over-the-counter turnover shrank to 90.4 million pesos from 130.3 million Wednesday.
"Institutional investors are stuck on the sidelines and therefore the market is moving in tight bands set by speculators," Lizzano saud.
Traders said the U.S. producer price index could help establish a clearer trend on the markets.
"We may go up or down depending on the outcome, but we're likely to see stronger volume," one trader said.
The broad market index closed off 0.5 percent, with losers pounding winners 42 to five and 12 issues closing flat.

Heaviest main-tier decliners were holding company Comercial del Plata, Banco Frances and construction stock Polledo, down 3.4 percent, 2.9 percent and 2.8 percent, respectively. Banco Frances was initiated as a "buy" near the close by UBS Securities.
The only MerVal risers were foods giant Molinos, Telefonica and power utility Central Costanera, which firmed 0.8 percent, 0.7 percent and 0.3 percent, respectively.
